title: Structured Logging Verbosity Levels
description: Verbosity level definitions and usage guidelines for Unreal Engine Structured Logging

use_when: Successful state transitions (e.g., agent possessed, broom mounted)
Expected behavior confirmations (e.g., perception detected target)
Regular workflow milestones (e.g., match started, goal scored)

examples.reason: Game mode transitioned to new state

use_when: Validation failures that have fallback behavior
Configuration issues that won't crash but should be fixed

examples.reason: Player tried to use spell without unlocking channel
Broom forced dismount due to stamina exhaustion

use_when: Operations that should succeed but failed (e.g., file I/O error)
Invalid state that indicates a bug (e.g., null pointer in initialized object)

examples.reason: AI controller couldn't start behavior tree
Async write thread couldn't write to disk

use_when: Critical system failures that prevent game from continuing
Fatal.note: Structured logging captures fatal errors without crashing. Use native ensure()/check() for actual crash behavior.

examples.reason: World context null when it must be valid

Verbose.description: Detailed tracing (high verbosity, disabled by default)
use_when: Debugging specific complex systems (e.g., pathfinding iterations)
Deep diagnostic traces (e.g., every blackboard read/write)
Verbose.note: Verbose logging generates high volume. Enable per-channel only when debugging specific systems.

examples.reason: Trace every blackboard access for debugging decorators
Log every stimulus evaluation, not just successful detections

choosing_verbosity: Default to Display for normal events
Use Warning for unexpected conditions that don't break functionality
Use Error for bugs and failures requiring developer attention
Reserve Verbose for temporary debugging, not production logging
verbosity_filtering: Override at runtime via console: slog.SetChannelVerbosity AI Warning
Focus mode automatically captures all verbosities for selected channels
